results.title: H.U.R.G. for ZX Spectrum 48K
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer program. Cassette, manual, cardboard cassette case and plastic cassette tray.
results.brief_description:
“H.U.R.G., High-Level User-Friendly Real-Time Games Designer”, is a program that enables you to create games. It is a menu driven utility designed to assist in creating games for the ZX Spectrum 48K and can be used by those with little or no knowledge of programming. For example, by using the ‘Edit Game’ menu option, the player can select actions such as creating a title page or specifying playing conditions via sub-menus. Utilities like these opened the possibilities for using home computers, by making programming accessible to anyone who was interested. Games created with “H.U.R.G.” are not stand-alone; they still require the engine to run.

“H.U.R.G.” came with three demo games that were created within the engine: ‘Manic Koala’, ‘Egg Pack’ and ‘Ms. Hortense’. Melbourne House ran competitions to encourage people to use “H.U.R.G.” in games design, with cash prizes for the best games created on the software.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/h-u-r-g-high-level-user-friendly-real-time-game-designer/

Last accessed: 5/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software. Published in 1984 by Melbourne House.

results.title: H.R. Pufnstuf: The wheely bird
results.brief_description: Jimmy, his magic flute Freddy and best friend H.R. Pufnstuf have to battle the evil Witchiepoo. In this episode, Jimmy and Pufnstuf use a bird-shaped “Trojan Horse” as a trick in order to enter Witchiepoo’s castle to recover the stolen Golden Flute Freddie.

results.title: H.R. Pufnstuf: the magic path
results.brief_description: On a walk through the forest, Jimmy and his magic flute Freddy are lured away by Witchiepoo to Living Island. They remain trapped when Witchiepoo makes the Magic Path disappear and Jimmy must rely on the resources and loyalty of his best friend H.R. Pufnstuf to get him out of trouble.

results.title: H.M.A.S. Voyager: the cruel legacy
results.creator_credit: Harvey Broadbent and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
On February 10th, 1964, the destroyer HMAS Voyager was sliced in two when it collided with her flagship aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne in Jervis Bay, off the coast of New South Wales. Voyager sunk with the loss of 82 men. This program attempts to piece together the final minutes before the fatal collision and the years of bitter neglect for the survivors of Voyager who are still fighting for justice and compensation. Their burden has been one of broken careers, sometimes broken marriages and often broken mental and physical health. Although two Royal Commissions have taken place, responsibility for the collision still remains unanswered, counselling and support have never been provided to the survivors and a certain amount of suspicion still exists about high-ranking naval personnel cover-ups. Reporter: Andrew Olle.

results.title: H.J. Maxwell: railroad engineer
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles. Dept. of Theater Arts and Trevor Greenwood
results.brief_description: A student documentary interview with H.J. Maxwell as he talks about his nearly 50 years with the Santa Fe Railway. Shows Maxwell working in the rail yards and looks at various procedures and different types of engines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: University of California, Los Angeles. Dept. of Theater Arts and Trevor Greenwood

results.title: H-16 camera with wood and aluminium tripod
results.brief_description:
The home-movie market took off after World War II. Enthusiasts across the world began to document their lives with a series of small, easy-to-use home-movie cameras that shot on 8mm and 16mm film. These were great introductory cameras for filmmakers – particularly the Swiss-made Bolex H16 camera, which is often used in film schools today. Directors and experimental filmmakers like David Lynch, Spike Lee and Maya Deren all started out using the Bolex H16.

H-16 camera with wood and aluminium tripod

Paillard Bolex, Switzerland, c. 1948
